instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 20V
threads.message: Hello. Got this board here that has bee cleaned by another store because of liquid damage, so I don't really know where original damage was. After some inspection I found a blown coil, L4004 was gone and so was its pin 1 trace, so I rebuilt it with a wire, there's no shorts I could find. As <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> area looked a bit bad I decided to replace <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> as board was not negotiating 20V with charger. I inspected all components around it and everything is measuring good. Before replacing it I was getting 5V, 50mA on all ports except the one corresponding to <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>. After replacement I now get 5V 50mA on all ports. I'm missing <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> but there are no shorts to GND on it. I'm stuck now. I'm having serious trouble to understand this messy USB-C architecture... I compared BMC diode readings from all ports and all of them give from 0.458 to 0.475, very similar readings, so I think probably all CD3215s are ok.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 20V
threads.message:
1V1 LDO must appear only on the powered USB port.
Is it present on the other 3 ports, missing only at <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>?

Compare diode mode readings of all LDO rails between the 4 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Do you get <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Any voltage at F7000?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 20V
threads.message:
All ports are missing that signal. Yes, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is present. Here we go:

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.474
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 0.495
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 0.461
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.477

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.167
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 0.496
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 0.462
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.477

UB300:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.472
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 0.477
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 0.446
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.461

UB400:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.471
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 0.476
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 0.445
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.458

Looks like <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is dead. Will replace it and post back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 20V
threads.message: All LDO diode mode readings are equal now, still no 20V and no BMC voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 20V
threads.message:
Did you check 1V1 LDO on each chip connecting charger to corresponding port?
Check <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and UB090 for corrosion; be sure all traces and surrounding components are good.

<SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 20V
threads.message: 1V1 LDO appears on the UB300 and UB400 side(both ports) but not on the other 2 ports. No corrosion and no missing/looking bad components around <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> or UB090. <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3V on all ports.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 20V
threads.message:
Then you still have a problem on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 area.
Compare diode mode readings to ground on several points of both left/right USB-C areas.
Check the value of all resistors from pages 28-30.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 20V
threads.message: I decided to check the value of all resistors around <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and found that <RESISTOR>R3205</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R3203</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R3209</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3208</RESISTOR> were all reading weird. So I replaced all of them. Now I have correct readings but still stuck on 5V and no <SIGNAL>LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> being generated on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 ports. Now, suddenly UB300/400 ports decided to keep resetting in loop. I'm almost throwing this board on the other side of the street.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 20V
threads.message:
Power cycling could be sign that board tries to start on UB300/400 side.
Possibly short, or overcurrent detected on secondary supplies...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 20V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 20V
threads.message:
Still problems on USB-C, as you don't have the same behavior on all ports.
But apart of that, there must be a problem with some secondary power rail.
What happens if you connect the battery (with some charge)?
